inclusion.criterion: histologically confirmed HER-2/neu-overexpressing adenocarcinoma of the breast
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: stable central nervous system (CNS) disease that has been adequately treated and is not under active treatment allowed
inclusion.label: unknown

inclusion.criterion: no systemic oral steroids administered within 28 days prior to initiating treatment on protocol
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: adequate bone marrow reserve with absolute neutrophil count (ANC) > 1000 and platelets > 100,000
inclusion.label: unknown

inclusion.criterion: adequate renal function with serum creatinine < 2.0
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: adequate hepatic reserve with serum bilirubin < 2.0, aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) < 2X the upper limit of normal, and alkaline phosphatase < 5X the upper limit of normal
inclusion.label: unknown

inclusion.criterion: adequate cardiac reserve with a cardiac ejection fraction within the lower limit of facility normal by MUGA, or 45% by echocardiogram
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: no active major medical or psychosocial problems that could be complicated by study participation
inclusion.label: unknown

exclusion.criterion: cardiac dysfunction documented by an ejection fraction less than the lower limit of the facility normal by multi-gated acquisition (MUGA) scan, or 45% by echocardiogram
exclusion.label: unknown

exclusion.criterion: symptomatic intrinsic lung disease or extensive tumor involvement of the lungs resulting in dyspnea at rest
exclusion.label: not_met

exclusion.criterion: history of autoimmune disease as detailed above
exclusion.label: not_met

exclusion.criterion: systemic oral corticosteroid treatment within 28 days prior to initiating treatment on study
exclusion.label: not_met

exclusion.criterion: evidence of active acute or chronic infection
exclusion.label: not_met

notes: Patient is a 22yo F with systemic mastocytosis, presenting with flushing and tachycardia. She responded well to IV steroids and diphenydramine.
